basics.name: Colbren Fujimoto
basics.label: Student
basics.summary: I am studying for a B.S. in Computer Engineering in the College of Engineering at the University of Hawaii. I expect to graduate in Spring, 2026. My current work involves robotic systems, satellites, and AI. I hope to work on embedded software for sensors on autonomous cars in the future.

work.summary: Develop real-time embedded software for NASA-contracted satellite missions
highlights: Developed and validated real-time embedded C++ software for NASA-contracted CubeSat missions, implementing robust control interfaces for EPS, ADCS, radio communication systems, and mission-critical onboard processes

Collaborated with avionics and mechanical teams for end-to-end CubeSat integration, including subsystem bring-up, firmware deployment, configuration, hardware checkout, and comprehensive telemetry verification in flight-representative environments
Developed automated tooling for data logging, test execution, and telemetry analysis, enabling efficient regression testing, rapid anomaly diagnosis, and improved mission readiness review workflows

work.position: AI Research Assistant - Dr. Liuwan Zhu
work.summary: Research in multimodal model safety, geolocation privacy, and medical AI
highlights: Quantified the contribution of fine-grained geolocation cues in images processed by OpenAI’s multimodal models and developed an automated counterfactual defense framework that strategically obscures sensitive visual features while preserving overall visual semantics

Developed a multimodal interpretability framework by integrating TokenSHAP and PixelSHAP to jointly analyze text and vision-based attribution patterns, enabling finer-grained measurement of how language cues and visual features interact during geolocation reasoning

Applied tree-based feature importance methods and fine-tuned model parameters on specialized biomedical datasets to evaluate LLM-assisted lung cancer detection, achieving improved diagnostic performance using a Random Forest classifier

work.summary: Worked on autonomous navigation, computer vision, and ground station of rover simulating mars missions
highlights: Developed a SLAM-driven autonomous path planner that optimized shortest-path routing and dynamic obstacle avoidance, improving exploration coverage efficiency by more than 40%
Designed and implemented a high-precision sensor-fusion pipeline combining RTK-GNSS, IMU, and wheel-odometry data, improving positional accuracy from ~3 m to roughly 10 cm
Leveraged a ZED 2i stereo camera with YOLOv8 for real-time object detection and ARUCO marker tracking, achieving over 90% detection accuracy in dynamic, real-world environments
Placed 7th place out of 114 international teams in the Science Mission at the University Rover Challenge

volunteer.summary: Lead developer for weather sensing project
highlights: Lead in providing mentorship for 3rd to 5th-grade students developing fundamental design principles and problem-solving skills through the engineering design process
Created the curriculum for a LEGO Mindstorms EV3 robotics camp; designed engaging engineering-related activities and challenges

awards.title: Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program (UROP)
awards.summary: Awarded $10,000 for research developing and testing autonomous navigation, control algorithms, and hardware integration for rover platforms to support future planetary exploration missions

awards.title: Hawaii Space Grant Consortium (HSGC) Grant
awards.summary: Secured $14,000 competitive grant to fund Team RoSE’s projects involving aerospace research

awards.title: Dean’s List (All semesters)
awards.summary: Awarded for maintaining a semester GPA of 3.5 or higher
